M96365

1



7 Sample(s), 0 Trip Blank(s) and 0 Field Blank(s) were collected on 12/02/2010 and were received at Accutest on 12/06/2010 properly 
preserved, at 1.7 Deg. C and intact.  These Samples received an Accutest job number of M96365. A listing of the Laboratory Sample 
ID, Client Sample ID and dates of collection are presented in the Results Summary Section of this report.

Except as noted below, all method specified calibrations and quality control performance criteria were met for this job. For more 
information, please refer to QC summary pages.

Client: Enchem Engineering,Inc.

Site: E & A Acton, MA

Job No M96365

Report Date 12/17/2010 4:16:05 PM

SAMPLE DELIVERY GROUP CASE NARRATIVE

Volatiles by GCMS By Method SW846 8260B
Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSG4107

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

Sample(s)  M96408-1MS, M96408-1MSD were used as the QC samples indicated.

Blank Spike Recovery(s) for  1,2,4-Trimethylbenzene, 1,3,5-Trimethylbenzene, Dibromochloromethane, Hexachlorobutadiene, 
Isopropylbenzene, p-Isopropyltoluene, sec-Butylbenzene, tert-Butylbenzene are outside control limits. Blank Spike meets program 
technical requirements.

Matrix Spike Recovery(s) for  2-Hexanone, Acetone, Hexachlorobutadiene, Isopropylbenzene, p-Isopropyltoluene, sec-
Butylbenzene are outside control limits.  Outside control limits due to possible matrix interference. Refer to Blank Spike.

Matrix Spike Duplicate Recovery(s) for  1,3,5-Trimethylbenzene, Acetone, Hexachlorobutadiene, Isopropylbenzene, p-
Isopropyltoluene, sec-Butylbenzene, Vinyl Acetate are outside control limits.  Outside control limits due to possible matrix 
interference. Refer to Blank Spike.

MSG4107-BS/BSD/MS/MSD for Vinyl Acetate: Outside control limits. Associated samples are non-detect for this compound.

Blank Spike Duplicate Recovery(s) for  Hexachlorobutadiene, Isopropylbenzene, p-Isopropyltoluene, sec-Butylbenzene are 
outside control limits. Blank Spike meets program technical requirements.

Continuing calibration check standard MSG4107-CC4085 for chloromethane, acetone, Tetrahydrofuran, isopropylbenzene, 
bromofluorobenzene, n-propylbenzene, 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene, tert-butylbenzene, 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene, sec-butylbenzene, p-
isopropyltoluene, hexachlorobutadiene exceed 20% Difference. This check standard met MCP criteria.

The response factor (RF) for the 2-Butanoe low point in the initial calibration MSG4085-ICC4085 is 0.082, less than the required 
RF of 0.1 as noted in Table 4 of SW846 8260C, but greater than 0.05.

Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSN1830

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

Sample(s)  M96407-4MS, M96407-4MSD were used as the QC samples indicated.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSN1832

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

Blank Spike Recovery(s) for  2-Butanone (MEK), 2-Hexanone, Acetone, Bromobenzene, Hexachlorobutadiene, Isopropylbenzene, 
n-Propylbenzene are outside control limits. Blank Spike meets program technical requirements.

RPD for MSN1832-BSD for Chloroethane: Outside control limits. Individual spike recoveries within acceptance limits.

MSN1832-MS for 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene, 1,2,3-Trichlorobenzene, Isopropylbenzene, Hexachlorobutadiene: Outside control 
limits due to possible matrix interference. Refer to Blank Spike.

Blank Spike Duplicate Recovery(s) for  2-Hexanone, Acetone, Isopropylbenzene, 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene are outside control 
limits. Blank Spike meets program technical requirements.

Quadratic regression is employed for initial calibration standard MSN1823-ICC1823 for iodomethane, 2,2-dichloropropane.

Friday, December 17, 2010 Page 1 of 2

4 of 25

M96365

2



Volatiles by GCMS By Method SW846 8260B
Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSN1832

The response factor (RF) for the 2-Butanoe low point in the initial calibration is 0.032, less than the required RF of 0.1 as noted in 
Table 4 of SW846 8260C.

Initial calibration verification standard MSN1823-ICV1823 for acetone, 2-butanone, 2-hexanone(33.6%) exceed 30% Difference.

Continuing calibration check standard MSN1832-CC1823 for bromomethane, chloroethane, iodomethane, dibromomethane, 
isopropylbenzene, bromofluorobenzene, bromobenzene, 1,2,3-trichloropropane, n-propylbenzene, 4-chlorotoluene, 1,3,5-
trimethylbenzene exceed 20% Difference. This check standard met MCP criteria.  

Accutest may not have met all requested limits due to methodology limitations, sample matrix, dilutions, or percents solids.

The Accutest Laboratories of New England certifies that all analysis were performed within method specification. It is further 
recommended that this report to be used in its entirety.The Accutest Laboratories of NE, Laboratory Director or assignee as verified 
by the signature on the cover page has authorized the release of this report(M96365).

1 Sample(s), 0 Trip Blank(s) and 0 Field Blank(s) were collected on 01/06/2011 and were received at Accutest on 01/07/2011 properly 
preserved, at 1.1 Deg. C and intact.  These Samples received an Accutest job number of M97072. A listing of the Laboratory Sample 
ID, Client Sample ID and dates of collection are presented in the Results Summary Section of this report.

Except as noted below, all method specified calibrations and quality control performance criteria were met for this job. For more 
information, please refer to QC summary pages.

Client: Enchem Engineering,Inc.

Site: E & A Acton, MA

Job No M97072

Report Date 1/14/2011 4:31:51 PM

SAMPLE DELIVERY GROUP CASE NARRATIVE

Volatiles by GCMS By Method SW846 8260B
Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSE2154

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

Blank Spike Recovery(s) for  1,4-Dioxane, 2-Butanone (MEK), 2-Hexanone, Acetone, Isopropylbenzene, trans-1,3-
Dichloropropene are outside control limits. Associated samples are non-detect for this compound.

Blank Spike Duplicate Recovery(s) for  1,4-Dioxane, 2-Butanone (MEK), Acetone, Isopropylbenzene, trans-1,3-Dichloropropene 
are outside control limits. Associated samples are non-detect for this compound.

Initial calibration verification standard MSE2153-ICV2153 for trans-1,3-dichloropropene, isopropylbenzene exceed  30% 
Difference

The response factor (RF) for the 2-Butanoe low point in the initial calibration MSE2153-ICC2153 is 0.022, less than the required 
RF of 0.1 as noted in Table 4 of SW846 8260C.  

Accutest may not have met all requested limits due to methodology limitations, sample matrix, dilutions, or percents solids.

The Accutest Laboratories of New England certifies that all analysis were performed within method specification. It is further 
recommended that this report to be used in its entirety.The Accutest Laboratories of NE, Laboratory Director or assignee as verified 
by the signature on the cover page has authorized the release of this report(M97072).

6 Sample(s), 1 Trip Blank(s) and 0 Field Blank(s) were collected on between 02/14/2011 and 02/21/2011 and were received at 
Accutest on 02/22/2011 properly preserved, at 1.5 Deg. C and intact.  These Samples received an Accutest job number of M97909. A 
listing of the Laboratory Sample ID, Client Sample ID and dates of collection are presented in the Results Summary Section of this 
report.

Except as noted below, all method specified calibrations and quality control performance criteria were met for this job. For more 
information, please refer to QC summary pages.

Client: Enchem Engineering,Inc.

Site: E & A Acton, MA

Job No M97909

Report Date 3/1/2011 2:34:32 PM

SAMPLE DELIVERY GROUP CASE NARRATIVE

Volatiles by GCMS By Method SW846 8260B
Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSG4173

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

BS/BSD Recovery(s) for  2-Butanone (MEK), 2-Hexanone are outside control limits.  Blank Spike meets program technical 
requirements.

MSG4173-BS/BSD for Acetone: Outside control limits. Associated samples are non-detect for this compound.

Continuing calibration check standard MSG4173-CC4151 for acetone (88.2%), 2-butanone, dibromofluoromethane, toluene-d8, 2-
hexanone exceed 20% Difference. Associate samples are non-detect for the compounds that have high responses exceeding 40%.

The response factor (RF) for the 2-Butanone low point in the initial calibration MSG4151-ICC4151 is 0.055, less than the required 
RF of 0.1 as noted in Table 4 of SW846 8260C, but greater than 0.05.

The Accutest Laboratories of New England certifies that all analysis were performed within method specification. It is further 
recommended that this report to be used in its entirety.The Accutest Laboratories of NE, Laboratory Director or assignee as verified 
by the signature on the cover page has authorized the release of this report(M97909).

9 Sample(s), 1 Trip Blank were collected on between 04/18/2011 and 04/19/2011 and were received at Accutest on 04/20/2011 
properly preserved, at 1.1 Deg. C and intact.  These Samples received an Accutest job number of M99541. A listing of the Laboratory 
Sample ID, Client Sample ID and dates of collection are presented in the Results Summary Section of this report.

Except as noted below, all method specified calibrations and quality control performance criteria were met for this job. For more 
information, please refer to QC summary pages.

Client: Enchem Engineering,Inc.

Site: E & A Acton, MA

Job No M99541

Report Date 4/28/2011 3:03:04 PM

SAMPLE DELIVERY GROUP CASE NARRATIVE

Volatiles by GCMS By Method SW846 8260B
Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSR773

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

BS/BSD Recovery(s) for  Isopropylbenzene are outside control limits.  Blank Spike meets program technical requirements.

Continuing calibration check standard MSR773-CC771 for toluene-d8, bromofluorobenzene exceed 20% Difference. This check 
standard met MCP criteria.

The response factor (RF) for the 2-Butanoe low point in the initial calibration MSR771-CC771 is 0.052, less than the required RF 
of 0.1 as noted in Table 4 of SW846 8260C, but greater than 0.05.

Matrix AQ Batch ID: MSR774

All samples were analyzed within the recommended method holding time.

All method blanks for this batch meet method specific criteria.

Continuing calibration check standard MSR774-CC770 for toluene-d8, bromofluorobenzene exceed 20% Difference. The 
continuing calibration was evaluated and met acceptance criteria for full list 8260.

The Accutest Laboratories of New England certifies that all analysis were performed within method specification. It is further 
recommended that this report to be used in its entirety.The Accutest Laboratories of NE, Laboratory Director or assignee as verified 
by the signature on the cover page has authorized the release of this report(M99541).

selected CAM protocols

Microsoft Word - Acton IRA Timeline


 IRA Timeline 
293-295 Main Street 

Acton, MA 
RTN 2-18260 

 
June 16, 2011:  Grab soil gas samples collected from 6 soil vapor points using summa canisters and 

submitted for laboratory analysis using EPA Method TO-15.  Points installed through the floor 
slab at Supercuts (293 Main St.), Dunkin Donuts (299, Main St.), Not Your Average Joe’s (305 
Main Street), Sleepy’s (307 Main Street) and near Middlesex Savings Bank. 

June 23, 2011:  Soil gas data received.  Elevated concentrations of PCE suggest potential for 
migration into indoor air and that indoor air sampling is warranted at Supercuts and Dunkin 
Donuts.  Levels of detected compounds beneath Not Your Average Joe’s, Sleepy’s and 
Middlesex Savings Bank suggest that potential for migration to indoor air is unlikely.  

July 1, 2011:  Indoor air samples collected using 8-hour summa canisters placed within Supercuts, 
Dunkin Donuts, and outdoors behind Dud’s Drycleaners. 

July 12, 2011:  Laboratory report of indoor air sampling received by EnChem at 3:00PM. Review of 
data indicated likely Imminent Hazard.  On behalf of E&A, EnChem provided 2-hour verbal 
notification to Mr. Kevin Daoust of MADEP at 4:20PM.  RTN 2-18260 issued. 

MADEP provided verbal approval for the following Immediate Response Actions: 

 Inspection of the floor within Supercuts/Duds to ensure that no obvious cracks etc. are 
present. 

 Potential fresh air ventilation of Supercuts. 
 Installation of a Soil Vapor Extraction System (or similar). 
 Calculation of a site-specific Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk. 

 
July 13, 2011:  Site meeting held with Mr. Daoust of MADEP at 10:30PM.  Preliminary inspection of 

Supercuts performed and no obvious cracks/pathways in the floor identified.  Mr. Daoust 
requested that an indoor an air sample be collected from within TC Lando’s.  Mr. Daoust agreed 
that indoor air sampling at the Bank would be appropriate.  MADEP requested that indoor air 
sampling be repeated within 2-3 weeks if the proposed SVE system is not running.  Indoor air 
sampling could be conducted at an unspecified later time after the SVE system is operational. 

July 14, 2011:  Jim Reagan of Environmental Systems, Inc. of Attleboro, Massachusetts adjusted the 
HVAC system to increase fresh air flow to Supercuts space. 

July 15, 2011:  Indoor air samples collected from Middlesex Saving Bank and TC Lando’s via 
summa canisters with 8-hour regulators. 

July 19, 2011:  Carbon filtration unit installed in Supercuts to improve indoor air quality. 

July 19, 2011:  Oral and written notification of potential Imminent Hazard provided to Supercuts. 

July 21, 2011:  MADEP modified the IRA to include the sampling of indoor air at Dud’s Cleaners at 
295 Main Street. 

July 21-22, 2011:  Horizontal SVE wells installed beneath the floor slab under Supercuts and Dud’s.  
Wells are 1-inch diameter with 10 foot long 10-slot screens. 

July 26, 2011(?):  Indoor air data from Middlesex Saving Bank and TC Lando’s received at 10:02 
AM. Data from Bank indicates no detectable compounds of concern.  Data from TC Lando’s 
indicates a potential Imminent Hazard. No additional RTN issued. 



July 26, 2011:  Indoor air samples collected from Supercuts and Dud’s using summa canisters with 8-
hour regulators. 

July 27, 2011:  Oral and written notification of potential Imminent Hazard provided to TC Lando’s. 
Mr. Daoust of MADEP informed of the condition at Lando’s via verbal communication. 

July 29, 2011:  Jim Reagan of Environmental Systems, Inc. of Attleboro, Massachusetts adjusted the 
HVAC systems at Duds and TC’s. 

July 29, 2011:  Carbon filtration unit installed in TC Lando’s to improve indoor air quality. 

August 5, 2011:  Indoor air samples collected in TC Lando’s. 

August 10, 2011:  Indoor air data from Supercuts and Duds received at 8:07 AM.  Data from Duds 
indicates a potential Imminent Hazard.  Mr. Daoust of MADEP informed of the condition via 
email. SVE/SSDS trailer and activated carbon units mobilized to site. 

August 11, 2011:  Three sub-slab vapor points installed inside Dud’s.  Vapor points in Dud’s and 
Supercuts screened with a PID. 

August 12, 2011:  One grab soil gas sample collected from Dud’s.  Two portable carbon filtration 
units installed inside Dud’s to improve indoor air quality.  SSD system turned on. 

August 15, 2011:  SSDS checked and vapor points inside Dud’s and Supercuts screened with a PID. 

August 18, 2011:  SSDS checked and vapor points inside Dud’s and Supercuts screened with a PID. 

August 19, 2011:  Indoor air samples collected in Dud’s (2), Supercuts, TC Lando’s and, Dunkin 
Donuts using summa canisters with 8-hour regulators. 

August 26, 2011:  SSDS checked and vapor points inside Dud’s and Supercuts screened with a PID. 

August 29, 2011:  SSDS checked and vapor points inside Dud’s and Supercuts screened with a PID. 

August 30, 2011:  Grab air samples collected from SSDS effluent before the activated carbon and 
after the two activated carbon units.

Acton Plaza 
293-295 Massachusetts Avenue 

 Acton, MA 01720 
 RTN 2-18260 
 

Dear Mr. Daoust.: 

Per your request, EnChem Engineering, Inc. (EnChem ) is providing a detailed, site specific calculation of the 
potential Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR) for the above referenced location related to indoor air sampling 
results obtained on July 12, 2011.  A copy of the laboratory report is attached.   
 
On behalf of Edens & Avant (E&A), EnChem provided 2-hour notification to MADEP at 4:20 PM on July 12, 
2011 for a potential “Imminent Hazard” related to elevated indoor air concentrations of tetrachloroethylene 
(PCE) measured within the space currently occupied by Supercuts.  This notification was provided in 
accordance 310 CMR 40.0321(2)(c) and  310 CMR 40.0993(6) since the concentration of PCE measured 
within Supercuts in sample designated IA-1 was greater than 10 times the concentration likely to pose an ELCR 
of one-in-one-hundred-thousand (3.4 ug/m3 from the Commercial/Industrial (C/I) standards indicated in Table 
I.2 and I-3, Appendix A of the “Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection Vapor Intrusion 
Guidance – Interim Draft”).  Release Tracking Number (RTN) 2-18260 was assigned to this potential 
condition. 
 
However, the C/I standards are calculated  based on a worker exposure period of 30 years and likely over-
estimate potential risks, for short-term exposures. For the purposes of evaluating a potential “Imminent 
Hazard”, per 310 CMR 40.0953(1) the period of time considered in the evaluation shall be 5 years (or shorter if 
circumstances indicate that the shorter time frame is appropriate).  At this Site, a 5 year period of time is likely a 
conservative estimate of potential risk moving forward since E&A has retained a Licensed Site Professional and 
authorized Immediate Response Actions (IRA) and Comprehensive Response Actions (CRA) to begin 
immediately, which is expected to shorten the potential exposure period.  However, to evaluate current 
conditions, and due to uncertainty regarding the prior indoor air quality, a period of evaluation of 5 years is 
likely appropriate and was used for the following calculations.  
 



151B California Street   Newton, MA 02458 
    Tel: 617‐795‐0058   Fax: 617‐795‐1669 

    www.en‐chem.com 
 
 
The attached calculations for a full-time worker (assumed to be present 5 days per week, for 8 hours per shift, 
for 5 years, with a 75 year averaging period for ELCR calculations) confirm that under current site conditions 
and “Imminent Hazard” likely exists and that an IRA is warranted.  A detailed Imminent Hazard Evaluation 
will be performed using indoor air data to be obtained after the IRA activities have been implemented. 
 

If you have any questions, please feel free to call the undersigned at (617) 795-0058. 

Sincerely, 

 

Raymond G. Ball, Ph.D., P.E.,L.S.P. 
Principal Engineer 
EnChem Engineering, Inc. 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



151B California Street   Newton, MA 02458 
    Tel: 617‐795‐0058   Fax: 617‐795‐1669 

    www.en‐chem.com 
 
 

EXCESS LIFETIME CANCER RISK CALCULATIONS 
293-295 Washington Street 

Acton, Massachusetts 
 
Calculation of Average Daily Exposure (ADE) for Indoor Air Exposures 
The average daily exposure to contaminants (ADE air) were calculated using the following 
formula: 

    ADE air = OHM air * EF * ED * EP * C 

       AP 

Where: 

OHM air = Exposure point concentration of gaseous or oil and hazardous material in the air at the 
exposure point during the period of exposure (in ug/m3). 

EF =  Number of exposure events (frequency) during the exposure period divided by the 
number of days in the exposure period.  Typical units are (events/day). 

ED= Duration of each exposure event.  Typical units are (hours/event). 
EP= Duration of exposure period (years). 
AP= Averaging period (years). 
C= Appropriate conversion factors.  For example, (1day/24 hours). 

INPUT VARIABLES USED TO CALCULATE FULL-TIME WORKER CASE ADEAIR 

OHM air 103 micrograms per cubic meter ( ug/m3) 

EF 5 events per week (full-time employee) 

ED 8  hours per event (typical full-time employee shift) 

EP 5 years 

AP 5 years for Threshold and 75 years for Nonthreshold 

C 1 day/24 hours (=0.0416667) 

 
By substitution of the above values the ADEair for this Site under Full-Time Worker conditions is  

 

103 ug/m3 * 5 events/7days * 8 hours/event * 5 years * 0.041667 days/24 hours 

75 years 



151B California Street   Newton, MA 02458 
    Tel: 617‐795‐0058   Fax: 617‐795‐1669 

    www.en‐chem.com 
 
 
 

ADEair = 1.6 ug/m3 
 
 
Estimated Lifetime Cancer Risk 
Cancer health effects are characterized by the Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR) index which 
estimates the incremental probability of an individual developing cancer over a lifetime as a 
result of exposure to contaminants.  The formula used to calculate ELCR is provided below: 

ELCR = ADE air * UR 

The unit risk factor for PCE is 1X 10-5 ug/m3 (from MADEP Shortform). 

The lowest calculated ADEair is 1.6 ug/m3 (assumes a 5-year exposure at the current 
concentration and that the person will then stop working at the site and will live for 75 years). 
Using this value in the above formula yields an ELCR of 1.6 X 10-5 or 1.6 in 100,000. 

Thus, for a full-time worker present 40 hours per week, under current site conditions, the ELCR 
is greater than 1 in 100,000.   

Hazard Index 
As presented in Table I.1 of the Vapor Intrusion Guidance, the concentrations of PCE and TCE 
that would exceed a Hazard Index (HI) of 0.2 is 1,300 and 53 ug/m3, respectively.  The 
maximum detected indoor air concentration of PCE and TCE measured at the Site are 103 ug/m3  
and 2.8 ug/m3, respectively which are well below the thresholds. Therefore a site specific HI was 
not calculated to evaluate an IH condition since the HI will be much less than 10.  

Imminent Hazard 
In accordance with 310 CMR 40.0955(2)(b)(c), a condition of “Imminent Hazard” exists if: 

 The HI calculated for the site is >= 10.0 and/or the total ELCR is greater than or equal to 1 in 
100,000 (1 x 10-5).  The ELCR is 1.6 per 100,000 for a full-time worker scenario, thus an 
Imminent Hazard is considered to exist at this Site under current site conditions and an IRA 
is warranted.

  www.en-chem.com 

   

 

 

 

IMMINENT HAZARD EVALUATION 

 

Duds Cleaners 

293-295 Main Street 

Acton, Massachusetts 01720 

RTN # 2-18260 

 

 

 

 

September 16, 2011 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Prepared For: 

 

            E&A Northeast Ltd. Partnership 

 21 Custom House Street, Suite #450 

      Boston, MA 02110 

 

 

 

Prepared By: 

 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 

151B California Street   

Newton, Massachusetts 02458 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

IMMINENT HAZARD EVALUATION 

DUDS CLEANERS 

293-295 MAIN STREET 

ACTON, MASSACHUSETTS 01720 

RTN # 2-18260 

 

 

On behalf of E&A Northeast Ltd. Partnership (E&A) of Boston, Massachusetts (E&A), EnChem 

Engineering, Inc., (EnChem) presents this Imminent Hazard Evaluation (IHE) prepared in 

accordance with 310 CMR 40.0950 of the Massachusetts Contingency Plan (MCP) for the above 

referenced site. This IHE is being presented as Appendix J of the attached Immediate Response 

Action (IRA) Plan being submitted for Release Tracking Number 2-18260.  

 

A 2-hour verbal notification for a potential Imminent Hazard was provided to the Massachusetts 

Department of Environmental Protection (MADEP) on July 12, 2011 by EnChem on behalf of 

E&A.  The notification was provided relative to elevated concentrations of tetrachloroethylene 

(PCE) and lesser concentrations of trichloroethylene (TCE) detected in indoor air samples 

collected within a retail space at the above property currently occupied by Supercuts.  The 

concentrations of PCE detected potentially constituted an Imminent Hazard (IH).  A preliminary 

IHE was provided to MADEP via email on July 15, 2011.  Results of the preliminary IHE 

confirmed that an IH did exist at the Site. A copy of the preliminary IHE is included as 

Appendix H of the attached IRA Plan.  

 

Since the date of notification, E&A has undertaken significant measures to mitigate the IH 

including: adjustment of the HVAC system to provide additional fresh air to the affected 

businesses, installation of portable granular activated carbon air filters in the affected businesses, 

and the installation of a soil vapor extraction (SVE) system. Details of previous assessment 

activities, IRA activities, results of ongoing assessment, laboratory reports, data tables, and 

figures are included in the attached IRA Plan. 

 

This IHE has been performed to determine if the IRA activities performed to date have mitigated 

the IH at the site. 

 

1.0  Exposure Assumptions 

 

As presented in the IRA Plan, the Site is currently in commercial use and is occupied by a dry 

cleaner, several restaurants, a liquor store, and a hair salon.  No institutions, residences, or 

drinking water receptors are present at or near the Site.  Children are present at the Site only as 

visitors for low-intensity activities.  Accordingly, the IH is being performed for an adult, full-

time worker present at the Site for 8-hours per day, 250 days per year (5 day work week for 50 

weeks per year).  Customers and other visitors to the Site are expected to be present at lower 

frequency and are therefore not considered further in this IHE. 

 

As demonstrated in the IRA Plan, a documented release(s) of PCE is known to have occurred at 

the Site. Soil under the building floor slab (currently inaccessible) and groundwater under and to 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

the rear of the building were determined to have been impacted by PCE, lesser quantities of 

TCE, and very minor amounts of cis 1,2-dichloroethylene.  Recent assessment identified the 

presence of PCE and TCE in soil vapor and indoor air samples.  Accordingly, only PCE and 

TCE in indoor air will be evaluated further. 

 

In accordance with 310 CMR 40.0953(1), a five year period of exposure will be evaluated.  The 

5 year exposure period is likely highly conservative considering the fact that an SVE system is 

currently in operation at the Site and concentrations of PCE and TCE detected in indoor air have 

significantly decreased since the SVE system began operations on August 12, 2011. 

 

Each separate business within the strip mall is climate controlled by an independent HVAC 

system.  Therefore, the indoor air in each individual business is considered as a separate 

exposure point.  

 

Historic soil data indicated that soil under the rear of Duds and Supercuts was most affected by 

the release.  Current soil vapor screening and sampling indicated that soil vapor concentrations 

were highest to the rear of the properties.  Accordingly, indoor air samples were collected from 

the rear of the businesses to be representative of worst case conditions.   

 

Data evaluated used in this IHE has been collected by EnChem in accordance with the 

Compendium of Analytical Methods and generally accepted industry practices.  The data 

evaluated herein is considered of sufficient accuracy and precision to be used for the purpose of 

performing this IHE.  Indoor air data evaluated herein is summarized in Table 4 of the IRA Plan. 

Copies of the laboratory analytical reports are provided in Appendix D of the IRA Plan.  

 

2.0 Hazard Index 

 

As defined at 310 CMR 40.0006, the hazard index (HI) is a calculation of the possibility of non-

cancer health effects as the result of exposure to one or more oil or hazardous materials (OHM) 

with the same or similar modes of toxic action or toxic endpoints. THE HI is calculated by 

dividing the daily dose (or daily concentration) of a particular OHM by the allowable daily dose 

(or daily concentration).  The allowable daily concentration is the Reference Concentration or 

other allowable daily concentration specified by MADEP. 

As presented in Table I.1 of the December 2010 MADEP Vapor Intrusion Guidance, the 

concentrations of PCE and TCE that would exceed a Hazard Index (HI) of 1.0 are 6,700 and 260 

ug/m
3
, respectively.  The maximum detected indoor air concentration of PCE and TCE measured 

at the Site are 259 ug/m
3
 and 181 ug/m

3
, respectively

 
which are well below these concentrations. 

Therefore, a site specific HI was not calculated to evaluate an IH condition since the HI will be 

much less than 10.  

  

 

 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

3.0    Evaluation of Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk 

 

The potential for carcinogenic (i.e., non-threshold) health effects is characterized as the Excess 

Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR). The ELCR represents the incremental probability of an individual 

developing cancer over a lifetime as a result of exposure to a potential carcinogen. For a give 

chemical, the estimated ELCR is the product of the receptor’s quantified exposure and a measure 

of the carcinogenic potency.  

 

As noted previously, an IH was identified due to elevated concentrations of PCE and lesser 

concentrations of TCE detected in indoor air samples collected within several operating 

businesses.  Accordingly, only PCE and TCE in indoor air are evaluated in the following 

calculations. 

 

Excess lifetime cancer risk (ELCR) was calculated in accordance with the MCP and Risk 

Characterization guidance using concentration. Measured indoor air data in each individual 

business (Supercuts, Duds, TC Landos, and Dunkin’ Donuts) were used to calculate the average 

daily dose of PCE and TCE.  The ADE was used in conjunction with MADEP specified cancer 

unit risk factors to calculate the ELCR. The specific formulas, data, and methods used to 

determine the site specific ELCR are presented in the following sections. Copies of the 

laboratory analytical reports are provided in Appendix D of the IRA Plan. Indoor air data 

evaluated herein is also summarized in Table 4 of the IRA Plan. 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

 

3.1  Calculation of Average Daily Exposure (ADE) for Indoor Air Exposures 

 

The average daily exposure to contaminants (ADE air) was calculated using the following 

formula obtained from the MADEP Shortform: 

    ADE air = OHM air * EF * ED * EP * C 

       AP 

Where: 

OHM air = Exposure point concentration of gaseous or oil and hazardous material in the air at the 

exposure point during the period of exposure (in ug/m3). 

EF =  Number of exposure events (frequency) during the exposure period divided by the 

number of days in the exposure period.  Typical units are (events/day). 

ED= Duration of each exposure event.  Typical units are (hours/event). 

EP= Duration of exposure period (years). 

AP= Averaging period (years). 

C= Appropriate conversion factors.  For example, (1day/24 hours). 

 

INPUT VARIABLES USED TO CALCULATE FULL-TIME WORKER CASE ADEAIR 

OHM air (Indoor air results) micrograms per cubic meter ( ug/m
3
) of PCE/TCE 

EF 1 event per day  

ED 8  hours per event (based on typical full-time worker shifts) 

EP 5 years (as specified per 310 CMR 40.0953(1)) 

AP 5 years for Threshold and 70 years for Non-Threshold ( Lifetime Cancer) Risks 

C 1 day/24 hours (=0.0416667)  

 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

 

Substituting the above values, the ADEair for this Site under Full-Time Worker conditions is: 

 

(OHM air) ug/m
3
 * 5 events/7days * 8 hours/event * 5 years * 1 day/24 hours 

70 years 

 

Table 1.  Calculations of ADEair 

Sample 

Location 
Sample Date OHMair PCE 

(ug/m3) 
OHMair TCE  

(ug/m3) 
ADEair PCE ADEair TCE 

Supercuts 7/1/11 103 15 1.752 0.255

3.2 Estimated Lifetime Cancer Risk Calculations 

Cancer health effects are characterized by the Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR) index which 

estimates the incremental probability of an individual developing cancer over a lifetime as a 

result of exposure to contaminants.  The formula used to calculate ELCR is provided below: 

ELCR = ADE air * UR 

The inhalation unit risk (UR) factor for PCE is 1X 10
-5
 ug/m

3 
(from MADEP Shortform). 

The inhalation UR for TCE is 1.7 X 10
-7
 ug/m

3
 (from MADEP Shortform).  The table below 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

shows the calculated ELCR for PCE and TCE for each sample location and date of sampling. 

Table 2.  Calculation of Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk 

Sample 

Location 
Sample Date ADEair PCE ADEair TCE ELCR PCE 

*10
-5 

ELCR TCE 

*10
-5 

Supercuts 7/1/11 1.752 0.255 1.75  0.011 

Supercuts 7/26/11 0.255 0.009 0.255  0.000 

Supercuts 8/16/11 0.054 0.008 0.054 0.000 

Dud’s(back) 7/26/11 4.065 3.078 4.065 0.128 

Dud’s(back) 8/19/11 2.551 1.032 2.551 0.043 

Dud’s(front) 8/19/11 0.150 0.323 0.150 0.013 

TC Landos 7/15/11 1.735 0.884 1.735 0.037 

TC Landos 8/5/11 1.020 0.561 1.020 0.023 

TC Landos 8/19/11 0.255 0.204 0.255 0.008 

Dunkin Donuts 7/1/11 0.425 0.044 0.425 0.002 

Dunkin Donuts 8/19/11 0.044 0.029 0.044 0.001 

Background 

(outdoor air) 
7/1/11 0.272 0.138 0.272 0.006 

Bank 7/15/11 ND ND ND ND 

 

As noted in Table 2 above, the ELCR in Supercuts was 1.75 in 100,000 using indoor air data 

obtained on July 1, 2011 indicating that an IH was present.  However, adjustments to the HVAC 

system and deployment of carbon filtration units decreased the ELCR in Supercuts to 0.26 in 

100,000 in a sample collected on July 26, 2011.  Using the results of an indoor air sample 

collected on August 19, 2011 after the SVE system had been operating for one week, the ELCR 

in Supercuts decreased to 0.054 in 100,000 (or 0.54 in 1,000,000). Thus, the most recent indoor 

air data indicates that the IH has been mitigated. 

The ELCR in TC Landos was 1.74 in 100,000 using results of the indoor air sample collected on 

July 15, 2011.  Adjustments to the HVAC system and deployment of carbon filtration units 

decreased the ELCR in TC Landos to 1.02 in 100,00 in a sample collected on August 5, 2011.  

These results indicated that an IH was present in this establishment. Using the results of an 

indoor air sample collected on August 19, 2011 after the SVE system had been operating for one 

week, the ELCR in TC Landos had been decreased to 0.255 in 100,000.  This data indicates that 

the IH has been mitigated in TC Landos. 

Indoor air data collected in Dunkin’ Donuts indicates that the ELCR was 0.425 in 100,000 in a 

sample collected on July 1, 2011.  In a sample collected on August 19, 2011 after the SVE 



 

 

 

 

 

 

  

system had been operating for one week, the ELCR in Dunkin Donuts had been decreased to 

0.044 in 100,000 (or 0.44 in 1,000,000).  Thus, the indoor air data indicates that an IH was not 

present in Dunkin Donuts and that IRA activities have significantly improved indoor air quality 

at this establishment. 

The lowest calculated ADEair is 1.6 ug/m
3
 (assumes a 5-year exposure at the current 

concentration and that the person will live for 70 years). Using this value in the above formula 

yields an ELCR of 1.6 X 10
-5 
or 1.6 in 100,000. 

Thus, even under the least conservative scenario, under current site conditions, the ELCR is 

greater than 1 in 100,000. 

4.0  CONCLUSION 

 

In accordance with 310 CMR 40.0955(2)(b), a condition of “Imminent Hazard” exists if the total 

ELCR is greater than or equal to 1 in 100,000 (1 x 10
-5
).  The ELCR calculated using indoor air 

data obtained on August 19, 2011 ranges between 2.6 and 0.15 per 100,000 in back and front of 

Dud’s respectively.   Thus an Imminent Hazard is considered to exist at this Site within the space 

occupied by Duds Cleaners. 

Additional IRA activities including expansion of the operating SVE system and in-situ chemical 

oxidation will be performed to mitigate the IH.  Details of the proposed additional IRA activities 

are included in the attached IRA Plan. 

 

References: 
 

1. MADEP: Shortform Method 3 Human Health Risk Assessment. Updated September, 

2008. 

2. MADEP: Interim Draft Vapor Intrusion Guidance December, 2010. 

3. MADEP: WSC/ORS #95-141: Guidance for Disposal Site Risk Characterization July, 

1995.
