IMMEDIATE RESPONSE ACTION PLAN 
DUDS CLEANERS 

293-295 MAIN STREET 
ACTON, MASSACHUSETTS 01720 

RTN # 2-18260 
 

1.0   INTRODUCTION 
 
On behalf of E&A Northeast Ltd. Partnership (E&A) of Boston, Massachusetts (E&A), EnChem 
Engineering, Inc., (EnChem) presents this Immediate Response Action (IRA) Plan that details 
response actions performed to date and proposed actions to be performed at the above-referenced 
location.  This IRA is being performed under Release Tracking Number 2-18260.  A 2-hour 
verbal notification for a potential Imminent Hazard was provided to the Massachusetts 
Department of Environmental Protection (MADEP) on July 12, 2011 by EnChem on behalf of 
E&A. 
 
In accordance with 310 CMR 40.0424 of the Massachusetts Contingency Plan (MCP), this IRA 
Plan includes the following: 
 
• the name, address, telephone number and relationship to the site of the person assuming 

responsibility for conducting the IRA; 
• a description of the release or threat of release, site conditions and surrounding receptors; 
• a description of the IRA activities performed to date  
• the reason why an IRA is required 
• the objective(s), specific plan(s) and proposed implementation schedule for the IRA, 

including, as appropriate, plans and/or sketches of the site, and any proposed investigative 
and/or remedial installations; 

• a statement as to whether Remediation Waste will be excavated, collected, stored, treated, or 
re-used at the site; 

• where appropriate, a proposed environmental monitoring plan, for implementation during 
and/or after the IRA 

• a listing of federal, state and/or local permits likely to be needed to conduct the IRA; 
• the seal and signature of the Licensed Site Professional who prepared the IRA Plan; 
• any other information that the Department, during its review and evaluation of the IRA Plan, 

determines to be necessary to complete said plan, in view of site specific circumstances and 
conditions. 

 
The Bureau of Waste Site Cleanup IRA Transmittal Form BWSC-105 has been submitted 
electronically via the MADEP eDEP system with this report. Additionally, a Release 
Notification Form BWSC-103 was submitted as a separate eDEP transaction. 
 
 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

1.1   Responsible Party and Site Contacts 
 
A written Notice of Responsibility (NOR) was issued by MADEP on July 29, 2011 with respect 
to this IRA. The NOR indicated that the operator/owner  of the active dry cleaner Kleenit, Inc. 
d.b.a Duds Cleaners, of 44 Park Street, Ayer, Massachusetts (hereinafter “Duds”) represented by 
Mr. Francis Murphy and E&A, the current property owner, were considered Potentially 
Responsible Parties (PRPs). 
 
The PRP assuming responsibility for the design, construction, and implementation of the 
proposed IRA at the site and contact information is: 
 

E&A Northeast Ltd. Partnership 
21 Custom House Street, Suite #450 
Boston, MA 02110 
Mr. Jonathan Dayton, Representative 
(617) 369-6600 

 
The LSP responsible for ensuring that the IRA conforms to all applicable requirements and 
deadlines is: 
 

 
Dr. Raymond G. Ball LSP # 4521 
EnChem Engineering, Inc. 
151B California Street 
Newton, Massachusetts 02458 
(617) 795-0058 
 

1.2 Description of the Release, Prior Investigations, and Regulatory History (Existing RTN 
2-14526) 
 
Environmental monitoring has been conducted at 293-295 Main Street since June 1998 when a 
Level II Environmental Assessment was conducted by Sanborn, Head & Associates, Inc. (SHA) 
on behalf of the property owner at the time, Acton Ventures/Samuels & Associates. A Site Locus 
Plan is shown in Figure 1. SHA advanced nine soil borings and completed seven of the borings 
as monitoring wells identified as MW-1 through MW-7 on Figure 2. Soil and groundwater 
samples were submitted to the laboratory and concentrations of tetrachlorethylene (PCE) were 
reported in soil and groundwater samples at levels below the MCP Reportable Concentrations 
(RCs) in effect at the time.  
 
In 2002, an additional subsurface investigation was conducted by SHA on behalf of the property 
owner at the time, E&A Northeast Limited Partnership (E&A). Prior to 2002 Duds occupied one 
space in the Acton Plaza building which was subsequently subdivided into two separate spaces, 
293 and 295 Main Street, with Duds remaining at 295 Main Street. SHA conducted the 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

subsurface investigation as part of this subdivision and on July 2, 2002 detected PCE in soils 
beneath the concrete slab at 293-295 Main Street. Coler & Colantonio, Inc. (C&C) was retained 
by Kleenit, Inc., the parent company of Duds, to evaluate the SHA findings and conduct 
additional groundwater sampling. Groundwater samples were collected from monitoring wells 
MW-2, MW-5, and MW-6 and were submitted to the laboratory which reported concentrations 
of PCE, trichloroethylene (TCE), and methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) above detection limits. 
Sub-slab soil gas samples were also collected beneath the 293 Main Street space and the 
laboratory reported concentrations of PCE, TCE, xylenes, and toluene in the samples above 
detection limits.  
 
Based on the soil, groundwater, and sub-slab gas analytical results reported in 2002, C&C 
determined that the PCE present in these samples constituted a 120-day reportable condition per 
310 CMR 40.315 of the MCP. Therefore, on behalf of Duds, C&C notified the MADEP on 
October 29, 2002 and RTN 2-14526 was assigned to the release.  
 
Following the release notification, C&C submitted a Phase I Initial Site Investigation Report 
(Phase I) and Tier Classification on October 29, 2003 classifying the Site as a Tier II disposal 
site. Based on an indoor air risk assessment completed as part of the Phase I, C&C reported that 
there was No Significant Risk of harm to human health regarding the potential migration of 
vapors emitting from the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) beneath the concrete slab. 
However, C&C reported in the Phase I that PCE concentrations were present in soil and 
groundwater at the Site above the applicable Method 1 cleanup standards.  
 
C&C continued the subsurface investigation at 293-295 Main Street between 2003 and 2005 
with the advancement of additional soil borings and monitoring wells both within the building 
footprint and behind the building in the paved parking area. On December 12, 2005 C&C 
submitted a Phase II Comprehensive Site Assessment Report (Phase II) and a Phase III-
Identification, Evaluation and Selection of Comprehensive Remedial Action Alternatives Report 
(Phase III) to the MADEP summarizing the results of the investigation and identifying the 
remedial alternatives available to address the contaminants of concern.   
 
C&C concluded in the Phase II that releases of PCE to the subsurface soil and groundwater had 
occurred at the site as a result of accidental spills which occurred between 1960 and 1983 during 
dry cleaning operations at the Site. C&C also concluded that a Condition of No Significant Risk 
did not exist at the site and Response Actions were necessary in order to achieve a Response 
Action Outcome. According to soil borings detailed in the Phase II and advanced by C&C in 
2005 and SHA in 2002, most of the contaminated unsaturated soil was located underneath the 
building.  A “hot spot” was identified in the approximate location of the former dry cleaning 
distiller at boring B-106 between 0 and 2.5 feet bgs with a PCE soil concentration of 797 parts 
per million (ppm). Between 5 and 7.5 feet bgs, the PCE soil concentration dropped to 37.6 ppm.  
Borings SH-2, CC-5, B-201, B-202, B-203 and B-204 were also identified to have 
concentrations of PCE greater than the current Method 1 S-3/GW-2 standard of 10 ppm.  These 
samples were collected between approximately 6 and 9 feet bgs.   
 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

The Phase III Report submitted along with the Phase II Report outlined six remedial alternatives 
to address the PCE concentrations in soil and groundwater at the site. The alternatives were 
presented as follows: 
 

• excavate a 15ft x 15ft x 9ft “hot spot” beneath the 295 Main Street (Duds) slab 
containing elevated PCE concentrations in soil in the vicinity of B-106 

• excavate a 45ft x 35ft x 10ft area beneath the 295 Main Street (Duds) slab containing 
elevated PCE concentrations in soil 

• install a vapor extraction system (VES) beneath the 293-295 slab to remove PCE vapors 
in soil 

• inject a chemical oxidant into the subsurface across a 45ft x 35ft grid in the 295 Main 
Street (Duds) space 

• inject a chemical oxidant across a 10ft x 10ft “hot spot” grid in the 295 Main Street 
(Duds) space in the vicinity of B-106 

• Monitor the reduction of PCE concentrations through Monitored Natural Attenuation 
 
C&C concluded that the selected remedial alternative was to excavate the 15ft x 15ft x 9ft “hot 
spot” beneath the 295 Main Street (Duds) slab containing elevated PCE concentrations in soil in 
the vicinity of B-106.   
 
On November 2, 2006, C&C submitted a Phase IV Remedy Implementation Plan (RIP) 
Extension Request to the MADEP requesting an extension for the excavation activities proposed 
in the December 12, 2005 Phase III Report. On February 6, 2007, C&C submitted a Phase IV 
RIP detailing the design and implementation of the “hot spot” excavation selected in the Phase 
III Report. The excavation limits included a 15ft by 15ft area within the Duds space with an 
anticipated excavation depth of 5 to 10 feet beneath the slab. C&C estimated that approximately 
75 to 100 cubic yards of soil would be excavated. If necessary, C&C proposed the installation of 
a passive sub-slab depressurization system within the excavated area consisting of a perforated 
PVC pipe vented outside the building. C&C anticipated that the excavation work outlined in the 
Phase IV RIP would be performed by Duds during the summer of 2007.  
 
At this current time, the excavation work proposed in the Phase IV RIP has not been performed 
by Duds at the 293-295 Main Street property.  EnChem Engineering, Inc. (EnChem) was 
retained in November, 2010 by the property owner, E&A, to continue investigative and remedial 
work at the Disposal Site.  
 
 

1.3   Site Description and Surrounding Receptors  
 
The area of the IRA is located within a strip mall, located on the south side of Main Street 
(Route 27), in a commercially zoned area of Acton, Massachusetts.  The strip mall (hereinafter 
referred to as “Upper Plaza”) consists of addresses 291 through 305 Main Street with addresses 
293 to 297 Main Street included in the area of the IRA. The UTM coordinates for the Site are: 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

Zone 19, Northing: 4705527, Easting: 298526; or 42° 28’ 33” – north, 71° 27’ 03” –west 
(42.475894, -71.451013).  The Site of the IRA is currently occupied by Supercuts (293 Main 
Street), Duds Cleaners (295 Main Street), TC Lando’s (297 Main Street) and includes a portion 
of the property to the rear of the existing building. The general site location is shown on Figure 
1.  The property (hereinafter “Upper Plaza”) is occupied by a single story, masonry structure 
with a slab-on-grade foundation and is surrounded by a paved parking lot. In addition to 
Supercuts, Duds, and Lando’s, the Upper Plaza is also currently occupied by a Dunkin Donuts, a 
Sleepy’s mattress store, a Not Your Average Joe’s restaurant, and a liquor store. There is a paved 
parking area in both the front and the back of the building. A paved access road that connects the 
front and back paved areas runs along the southwestern side of the building. The topography of 
the Upper Plaza is mostly level, although at the southeastern edge of the back parking lot it drops 
off sharply to a neighboring shopping center.  The neighboring shopping center (hereinafter 
referred to as “Lower Plaza”) is also owned by E&A.  Upper and Lower Plaza are currently 
served by municipal water and sewer services as well as natural gas and electric utilities.  Prior 
to connection to the municipal sewer in 2002, the Upper Plaza used a septic tank and leach field, 
located southeast of the building.   
 
Relevant portions of Upper and Lower Plaza including monitoring well locations are shown on 
Figure 2. Note that the groundwater containing PCE on the Lower Plaza property is not the focus 
of the IRA, although a portion of the Lower Plaza property has been impacted by the release at 
Duds on Upper Plaza.  Additional assessment is ongoing at Lower Plaza (and Upper Plaza) to 
determine the full nature and extent of contamination associated with the release from Duds for 
which this IRA is being conducted.   

The property boundary of Raymond J. Grey Junior High School is located within 500 feet west 
of Upper Plaza property line while the school building is situated more than 500 feet from the 
Site.  No other “Institutions,” as defined in 310 CMR 40.0006, are known to be located within 
500 feet of the Site. 
 
The groundwater categories for the Site were determined pursuant to 310 CMR 40.0932. 
According to information provided by the BWSC Priority Resource Map (accessed 12/28/10) for 
the Site, the Site is not located within 500 feet of a potentially productive aquifer, Zone II, 
Interim Wellhead Protection Area, surface water supply, or Areas of Critical Environmental 
Concern.  The Town of Acton’s Aquifer Protection By-Law does not apply to this Site. 
Additionally, no private drinking water wells were identified within 500 feet of the Site.  
Accordingly, groundwater category GW-1 does not apply at the Site. 
 
Groundwater Category GW-2 is applicable at areas of the Site within 30-feet of the on-Site 
buildings since the average depth to groundwater is less than 15 feet below grade. Since all 
groundwater is presumed to eventually discharge to surface water Groundwater Category GW-3 
also applies. 
 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

The applicable Soil Category for the Disposal Site or “the Site” was identified pursuant to 310 
CMR 40.0933.  Currently, the Site is in solely commercial use with no residents present.  Adults 
working at the Site are present at the Site with high frequency (8-hour shifts), while children are 
considered present at the Site with low frequency.  Intensity of site use is low as no soil 
disturbing activities are conducted at the Site.  The area within the Disposal Site that is the focus 
of this IRA is entirely paved or occupied by buildings. Therefore, the applicable soil category 
within the area of the IRA at the Disposal Site is S-3/GW-2, GW-3.  Soil category S-1 will also 
be evaluated to determine if an Activity and Use Limitation could be required.  

1.4  Reason for IRA 
 
On July 12, 2011 at approximately 3:00PM, EnChem Engineering, Inc. received a copy of 
laboratory results from indoor air samples collected from within Supercuts and Dunkin Donuts 
on July 1, 2011. The indoor sampling was performed due to the detection of significantly 
elevated concentrations of tetrachloroethylene (PCE) and elevated concentrations of 
trichloroethylene (TCE) within soil gas beneath the building slab associated with known historic 
releases of PCE from Duds Cleaners operations. 
 
A summary of the indoor air laboratory data is provided in the table below. Sample IA-1 was 
collected from within Supercuts.  Sample BACK-1 was collected outside the building behind 
Dud’s Cleaners.  Sample IA-2 was collected from within the rear of Dunkin’ Donuts.  
 
Sample Designation (Location) Tetrachloroethylene (PCE) (ug/m3) Trichloroethylene (TCE) (ug/m3) 

IA-1 (Supercuts) 103 15 
BACK-1 (Outside in rear of Duds) 16 8.1 

IA-2 (Dunkin Donuts) 25 2.6 
 
These concentrations were compared to the Commercial/Industrial (C/I) standards indicated in 
Table I.2 and I-3, Appendix A of the “Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection 
Vapor Intrusion Guidance – Interim Draft” dated December, 2010.  A summary of these standards 
is shown below. 
 
Chemical Threshold Value C/I (ug/m3) Hazard Index = 1.0(ug/m3) ELCR = 1.0 X 10-5(ug/m3) 

PCE 4.1 6,700 3.4 
TCE 2.0 260 20 

NOTES:   
1) Commercial/Industrial Threshold Values (TVs) 
These values can aid in the consideration of whether measured indoor air concentrations 
are within the range of typical commercial and industrial concentrations. The values are 
largely risk-based using typical exposure scenarios for commercial and industrial 
settings.  

 
2) Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR) 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

ELCR is defined in the MADEP document “Indoor Air Sampling and Evaluation Guide 
(WSC Policy #02-430) dated April 2002”. The potential for carcinogenic (i.e., non-
threshold) health effects is characterized as the Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk (ELCR). 
The ELCR represents the incremental probability of an individual developing cancer over 
a lifetime as a result of exposure to a potential carcinogen. For a given chemical, the 
estimated ELCR is the product of the receptor’s quantified exposure and a measure of the 
carcinogenic potency.  

 
As noted in the above table, the results above indicate that the measured indoor (and outdoor) air 
concentrations are above the Threshold Values and above the ELCR standards. In particular, the 
concentration of PCE in sample IA-1 is greater than 10 times the ELCR standard. Thus, in 
accordance with 310 CMR 40.0321(2)(c) “For the purposes of fulfilling the “Two Hour” Release 
notification obligations of 310 CMR 40.0311(7), the following releases could pose an Imminent 
Hazard” Section (c) of 310CMR 400321(2) “a release to the environment for which estimated 
long-term risk levels associated with current exposures are greater than ten times the Cumulative 
Receptor Risk Limits in 310 CMR 40.0993(6)”. 
 
On behalf of E&A, EnChem provided the required 2-hour notification to Mr. Kevin Daoust of 
MADEP at 4:20 PM on July 12, 2011.   Release Tracking Number 2-18260 was assigned to the 
Site. 
 

2.0   MADEP APPROVED IRA ACTIVITIES 
 
On July 12, 2011 at the time notification was provided, the MADEP provided verbal approval 
for the following IRA activities: 
 

• Inspection of the floor within Supercuts/Duds to ensure that no obvious 
cracks/preferential migration pathways for vapors etc. were present.    

• Sealing/patching of any cracks/preferential pathways identified during inspection. 
• Potential fresh air ventilation of Supercuts. 
• Installation of a Soil Vapor Extraction System, sub slab ventilation, and/or sub slab 

depressurization system, which ever would be most effective by August 12, 2011. 
• Calculation of a site-specific Excess Lifetime Cancer Risk 

 
On July 13, 2011 at approximately 10:15 AM Mr. Kevin Daoust from the MADEP conducted a 
scheduled site meeting in response to the required 2-Hour Notification.  At the site meeting, 
MADEP requested that the following additional IRA activities be performed: 
 

• Collect an indoor air sample within T.C. Lando’s sub shop. 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

• Collect either an indoor air sample from within the Middlesex Savings Bank 
(located to the west of Supercuts) or soil vapor samples from the driveway between 
the buildings.   

• Periodically resample indoor air within Supercuts to assess the effectiveness of 
ventilation. 

 
On July 21, 2011, MADEP verbally modified the IRA to include the sampling of indoor air at 
Dud’s.  
 
On July 29, 2011, a written NOR issued by MADEP required that a Tier Classification or 
Response Action Outcome Statement by submitted with respect to this release on or before July 
12, 2012. No additional approvals or requirements were specified with respect to this IRA. 

3.0   PRE-IRA ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES 
 
As noted in Section 1.3, Comprehensive Response Actions were initiated by Dud's under RTN  
2–14526 to address historic releases of PCE. However, planned Phase IV Comprehensive 
Response Actions were not conducted by Dud's. Accordingly, E&A contracted EnChem in 
November 2010 to perform site assessment activities and potential site remediation since Dud's 
did not perform the planned Comprehensive Response Actions within the required timeframe 
defined by the MCP 310 CMR 40.0000. On behalf of E&A, EnChem completed the following 
assessment activities prior to the 2-hour notification on July 12, 2011: 
 

• December 2, 2010: Collected baseline gauging data and collected groundwater samples 
from existing monitoring wells. Groundwater gauging data is summarized in Table 1.  
Groundwater sampling results are summarized in Table 2. Groundwater analytical 
reports are provided in Appendix A. Based on the presence of a known, historic 
release(s) of PCE, groundwater samples were analyzed for the presence of volatile 
organic compounds (VOCs) using EPA Method 8260.   

• Feb. 14-15, 2011:  Installed monitoring wells EC-7 through EC-10 on Lower Plaza using 
a Geoprobe.  Refusal encountered on Upper Plaza prior to encountering the water table. 
Wells EC-1 through EC-4 could not be installed.  

• April 14-15, 2011:  Installed monitoring wells EC-1 through EC-4 on Upper Plaza using 
hollow stem augers and an air hammer as needed. Boring logs/well construction diagrams 
are included in Appendix B. 

• April 18, 2011: Performed comprehensive well gauging and prepared a groundwater 
contour map (Figure 3).  Referring to Figure 3, groundwater flow is generally to the 
west-southwest from Upper Plaza towards Lower Plaza. 

• April 18-19, 2011:  Performed additional groundwater sampling. Groundwater sampling 
results are summarized in Table 2. Groundwater analytical reports are provided in 
Appendix A. 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

• May and June 2011: Soil vapor points installed through the floor slabs at Sleepy’s, 
Dunkin' Donuts, Not Your Average Joe's, and Supercuts. Locations of the soil vapor 
points are shown on Figure 2.   

• June 16, 2011: Grab soil vapor samples collected from six soil vapor points using summa 
canisters and submitted for laboratory analysis using EPA Method TO–15.   

• June 23, 2011: Soil vapor sampling results were received.  Soil vapor analytical results 
are summarized in Table 3.  Soil vapor analytical reports are provided in Appendix C. 
Concentrations of detected compounds beneath Not Your Average Joe's, Sleepy’s, and 
Middlesex Savings Bank suggested that the potential for migration to indoor air was 
unlikely. However, elevated concentrations of PCE in soil gas samples collected beneath 
floor slab at Supercuts and Dunkin' Donuts suggested a potential for migration to indoor 
air. 

• July 1, 2011: Indoor air samples were collected using summa canisters equipped with 8-
hour regulators from within Supercuts, from within Dunkin' Donuts, and from outdoors 
behind Dud's. Indoor air analytical results are summarized in Table 4.  Indoor air 
analytical reports are provided in Appendix D. 

 
All samples collected by EnChem were submitted to Accutest Laboratories of Marlboro, 
Massachusetts (Accutest) for analysis under standard chain-of-custody protocols.  EPA Method 
8260 was utilized for groundwater sampling analysis and EPA Method TO-15 was used to 
analyze all air based samples such as soil vapor, and indoor air. 

 
A detailed plan showing locations of monitoring wells, soil gas sampling points, and indoor air 
sampling locations relevant to this IRA is included in Figure 4.   
 
As noted in Table 2, groundwater sampling indicated that concentrations of PCE above the 
applicable Method 1 GW-2 groundwater standards are present at monitoring wells on the Upper 
and Lower Plaza properties in December 2010 and/or April 2011, with the most significantly 
impacted well being CC-4 (PCE concentration of 4,680 micrograms per liter (ug/l) measured on 
December 2, 2010), which is located immediately adjacent to and down gradient of Dud’s. Wells 
EC-2, MW-2, MW-6, CC-5 and CC-102 on Upper Plaza indicated concentrations of PCE above 
Method 1 GW-2 standards also but at lower concentrations than CC-4 (concentrations of PCE 
ranged between 259 ug/l at MW-6 to 346 ug/l at well CC-5). 
 
Concentrations of PCE above applicable Method 1 GW-2 standards were reported in monitoring 
wells MW-7, EC-9, and EC-10 in groundwater samples collected in December 2010 and/or April 
2011.  Concentrations of detected compounds were significantly lower in monitoring wells 
located on Lower Plaza. Concentrations of PCE measured at the Lower Plaza ranged between 
1.1 ug/l at well EC-7 to a maximum of 87.5 ug/l at monitoring well EC-9.  Additional 
assessment via the installation of new monitoring wells and soil gas sampling points will be 
performed as needed and required in accordance with the MCP to fully define the nature and 
extent of contamination at both the Upper and Lower Plaza properties. 
 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

Additional compounds consistent with the historic use of PCE were detected in groundwater 
including TCE and cis1,2-DCE in 9 of the 16 monitoring wells sampled in 2010 and/or 2011.  
However, the concentrations of these compounds in groundwater were below the applicable 
Method 1 GW-2 standards.   Very low concentrations of methyl-tert butyl ether (MTBE), 
toluene, and total xylenes were also detected in wells EC-4 and EC-7.  Accordingly, only 
chlorinated solvents are considered compounds of concern at this Disposal Site. 
 
EnChem installed soil vapor points in May and June 2011 in multiple locations within Upper 
Plaza to further assess the potential risk to indoor air. Results of soil gas sampling (Table 3) 
performed on June 16, 2011 indicated significant concentrations of PCE were present at vapor 
points VP-SC-1 & 2 in Supercuts and at VP-DD-1 under Dunkin’ Donuts. Included in Table 3 is 
sub-slab soil gas data collected by C&C in October 2002 from beneath Supercuts. The 2002 
results are over five orders of magnitude lower than the recent data collected in June 2011. 
Lower concentrations of PCE were detected in vapor points VP-J-1 at Not Your Average Joe’s 
Restaurant, VP-SL-1 at Sleepy’s mattress store, and VP-B-1 located in the sidewalk at the rear of 
the bank. The soil gas sampling results indicated a potential for risk to indoor air at Supercuts 
and Dunkin’ Donuts. Accordingly, indoor air samples were collected from within Supercuts and 
Dunkin’ Donuts on July 1, 2011. 
 
As noted in Section 1.4, the results of indoor air sampling (Table 4) performed on July 1, 2011 
suggested that an Imminent Hazard (IH) was present within Supercuts and 2-hour notification 
was provided to MADEP on July 12, 2011.  An IH was not likely present within Dunkin’ 
Donuts. 
 
The results of assessment performed in late 2010 and 2011 indicate that current site conditions 
are significantly different than conditions as presented at the time of the Phase II submitted in 
2005 by C&C on behalf of Duds.  Accordingly, significant additional assessment and remedial 
activities are being proposed such that appropriate IRA and Comprehensive Response Actions 
may be conducted.   
 
Details of the findings of current assessment activities will be provided in a Revised Phase I Site 
Assessment and Tier Classification (as required by the NOR) and a Revised Phase II 
Comprehensive Site Assessment.  Details of proposed remedial activities, beyond those 
presented as part of this IRA Plan and any IRA Plan Addenda (if warranted) will be presented in 
a revised Phase III Remedial Action Plan, and a Revised Phase IV Remedy Implementation Plan.  
At a minimum, the Phase I and Tier Classification will be submitted on or before July 12, 2012 
as required by the NOR. 
 

4.0   COMPLETED IRA ACTIVITIES 
 
The following sections provide a summary of IRA activities completed between July 12 and 
September 18, 2011.  These activities were completed in accordance with verbal authorization 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

obtained from MADEP as described in Section 2.0.  A chronological summary of IRA activities 
completed to date is included in Appendix E. 

4.1 Adjustment of Building HVAC System 
 
In an effort to improve indoor air quality as quickly as possible, on July 14, 2011 Mr. Jim 
Reagan of Environmental System, Inc. of Attleboro, Massachusetts adjusted the building’s 
HVAC system to increase pressure and fresh airflow to the Supercuts space.  The HVAC system 
was also adjusted on July 29, 2011 to increase air pressure and fresh airflow to TC Lando's and 
Dud's. Based on subsequent indoor air sampling results the HVAC system adjustments appear to 
have improved indoor air quality. 
 

4.2 Installation of Granular Activated Carbon Indoor Air Filtration Units 
 
On July 19, 2011, EnChem installed a portable carbon filtration unit in Supercuts to improve 
indoor air quality. On July 29, 2011 a carbon filtration unit was also installed inside TC Landos. 
On August 12, 2011 two portable carbon filtration units were installed inside Dud's to improve 
air quality. The carbon filtration units operate continuously. Technical specifications for the air 
filtration units are included in Appendix F. 
 

4.3 Installation of Soil Vapor Extraction System 
 
Between July 21 and July 22, 2011, two horizontal vapor extraction wells were installed directly 
beneath the floor slab under Supercuts and Dud's as part of a Sub Slab Depressurization (SSD) 
system to mitigate vapor intrusion from below the floor slab into the indoor air of the building. 
The wells were installed by Crawford Drilling Services of Westminster, Massachusetts (CDS) 
under the supervision of EnChem.  The wells were installed using a vacuum truck equipped with 
an air lance. The wells were constructed of 1-inch diameter PVC with 10-foot long, 10-slot 
screens.  The approximate location of the two horizontal vapor extraction wells is indicated on 
Figure 4.  
 
Between July 21 and August 9, 2011 a mobile soil vapor extraction (SVE) treatment trailer unit 
was constructed to provide air vacuum to the two horizontal vapor extraction wells and act as a 
SSD system.  It was anticipated that the same SVE treatment trailer would also provide vacuum 
for future wells acting as a soil vapor extraction system for soil remediation in addition to vapor 
mitigation. The SVE trailer is fully enclosed and is approximately 6‘ wide by 8’ long.  The 
trailer is equipped with ventilation ports, a thermostatically controlled cooling fan, and a 
thermostatically controlled heater.  The SVE vacuum blower is a 2.5 horsepower, single-phase 
power, 60 hertz, Gast Regenerative Blower.  The SVE vacuum blower is capable of drawing up 
to 60 inches of water (inH2O)) column vacuum.  Air flow ranges between approximately 50 
cubic feet per minute (cfm) at the maximum vacuum of 60 inH20 and 140 cfm at 1 inH2O.  The 
SVE vacuum blower is fitted with a dilution valve to allow vacuum to be adjusted prior to the 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

blower.  Sample ports and vacuum gauges were installed prior to the dilution valve, after the 
dilution valve and prior to the blower, and after the blower.  Parts have been ordered to allow the 
SVE system to restart automatically after a power outage.  These parts will be installed as soon 
as they are obtained. 
 
Off-gas from the SVE system is treated using two 500-pound vapor phase granular activated 
carbon (VGAC) units piped in series.  Exhaust from the VGAC units is vented above the roof of 
the building.    
 
On August 10, 2011 the SVE trailer and VGAC units were delivered to the Site.  The SVE wells 
were individually piped to a common manifold and connected to the SVE blower on August 10 
and 11.  Each leg of the SVE system has a sample port and ball valve such that each well can be 
operated and screened/sampled independently. The SVE system began full-time operations on 
August 12, 2011. The location of the SVE system is indicated on Figure 4.  
 

4.4 SVE System Operations and Maintenance (O&M) 
 
Details of operations and maintenance (O&M) activities are presented in the following sections.  
The location of the SVE system, SVE wells, and soil vapor points are indicated on Figure 4.  
 
 4.4.1   System Status Inspections 
 
System inspections were performed on August 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 26, 29, 30, September 7 
September 10, and September 23, 2011.  Currently the SVE system is being operated at an 
influent vacuum of approximately 10 inH2O and an air flow rate of approximately 130 cfm. 
 
The system was operational for the entire period with the exception of August 28 when power to 
the Disposal Site failed at approximately 12 noon due to Tropical Storm Irene.  The system was 
manually restarted at approximately 10:20AM on August 29, 2011 after power to the Site was 
restored.  Thus, system uptime during the period between August 12 and September 15, 2011 (35 
days) was approximately 97% and no mechanical or operational problems occurred during this 
period.  
 
Parts have been ordered to allow the SVE system to restart automatically after a power outage 
and will be installed upon receipt.  The automatic restart capability should further improve 
system uptime. 
 

4.4.2   Remedial Air Emissions  
 
SVE air emissions are being monitored in accordance with 310 CMR 40.0049 and DEP Policy # 
WSC-94-150 “Off-Gas Treatment of Point Source Remedial Air Emissions”. The SVE influent 
effluent and midpoint have been screened periodically using a calibrated photoionization 
detector (PID). Influent PID concentrations were approximately 123 parts per million by volume 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

(ppmv) (after the fresh air intake) at system start up and have decreased to approximately 9.2 
ppmv (prior to the fresh air intake as of September 13, 2011.  Note: True influent PID 
measurements would be expected to be higher than 123 ppmv, because the influent air was 
somewhat diluted with ambient air when this initial measurement was taken. 
 
Samples of the SVE influent, effluent, and midpoint were collected on August 30, 2011 in Tedlar 
bags and submitted to Accutest for analysis of chlorinated solvents using USEPA Method TO-
15.  A copy of the analytical report is provided in Appendix G.  The influent concentration of 
PCE was 22,000 micrograms per cubic meter (ug/m3). TCE was not detected in the influent, with 
a laboratory detection limit of 21 ug/m3.  The concentration of PCE in the final effluent was 468 
ug/m3 and the concentration of TCE was 3.3 ug/m3 (which is below the commercial/industrial 
threshold value for indoor air).  Thus, PCE removal efficiency was approximately 98%.  
However, the TCE removal efficiency was approximately 85%.  Accordingly, the carbon in the 
primary and secondary units was replaced on September 13, 2011.   
 
 4.4.3  Vacuum Influence Measurements 
 
During SVE O&M visits, vacuum at soil vapor (SV) points within Duds and Supercuts has been 
periodically measured.  Vacuum at the SV points ranged from 0.02-0.04 inH2O at SV points VP-
D-1 to as high as approximately 1.06 inH2O at vapor point VP-SC-1. Locations of VPs are 
shown on Figure 4.  The vacuum measurements indicate that the SVE system is achieving 
vacuum influence under the floor slab beneath Duds and Supercuts. Vacuum measurements are 
summarized in Table 5. 
 

4.4.4  Soil Vapor Screening 
 
On August 11, 2011 the evening prior to SVE start up vapor points  VP-D-1, VP-D-2, and VP-
D-3, which are located in Duds, were screened with a PID and had readings of 450, 475, and 145 
ppmv, respectively.  Within Supercuts vapor points VP-SC-1 and VP-SC-2 had PID readings of 
33 and 6.6 ppmv, respectively. Following system startup on August 12, the system was 
temporarily deactivated on August 18, 26, 29, and September 13, 2011 (for a period of 
approximately 30 minutes) and the vapor points were screened with a PID. On August 18, 2011, 
vapor points VP-D-1, VP-D-2, and VP-D-3 had PID readings of 8.5, 4.9, and 93 ppmv, 
respectively. Within Supercuts, vapor points VP-SC-1 and VP-SC-2 had PID readings of 18.1 
and 15.9 ppmv, respectively. 
 
On August 26, 2011, vapor points VP-D-1, VP-D-2, and VP-D-3 had PID readings of 2.2, 1.6, 
and 43.2 ppmv, respectively.  Within Supercuts, vapor points VP-SC-1 and VP-SC-2 had PID 
readings of 6.7 and 9 ppmv, respectively. On August 29, 2011, vapor points VP-D-1, VP-D-2, 
and VP-D-3 had PID readings of 5.8, 4.7, and 47.4 ppmv, respectively.   Within Supercuts, vapor 
points VP-SC-1 and VP-SC-2 had PID readings of 3.4 and 22.4 ppmv, respectively.  
 
On September 13, 2011, vapor points VP-D-1, VP-D-2, and VP-D-3 had PID readings of 3.3, 
1.1, and 29 ppmv, respectively. Within Supercuts, vapor points VP-SC-1 and VP-SC-2 had PID 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

readings of 2.4 and 2.6 ppmv, respectively. This data indicates that overall soil vapor 
concentrations have decreased significantly since the SVE system began operations. Soil vapor 
screening results are summarized in Table 3.   
 

4.5 Preliminary Imminent Hazard Evaluation 
 
A preliminary Imminent Hazard (IH) Evaluation was performed using the indoor air data 
collected on July 1, 2011 (see Section 1.4 for details).  The preliminary IH evaluation concluded 
that an IH existed in Supercuts.  This report was submitted to Mr. Kevin Daoust of MADEP via 
email on July 15, 2011.  A copy of this evaluation is included in Appendix H.  

4.6 Indoor Air Sampling 
 
Since commencing IRA activities, indoor air samples have been collected from selected 
businesses within and/or adjacent to the Site on July 15, July 26, August 5, and August 19, 2011.  
All indoor air samples have been collected using 6-liter Summa canisters equipped with 8-hour 
regulators.  All indoor air samples collected have been submitted to Accutest for analysis for the 
presence of chlorinated solvents using EPA Method TO-15. Indoor air sampling locations are 
indicated on Figure 4. Indoor air analytical results are summarized in Table 4.  Laboratory 
analytical reports are included in Appendix D. 
 
Per the request of MADEP, an indoor air sample was collected from within Middlesex Savings 
Bank (located across a driveway adjacent to Supercuts) and TC Landos (sub shop and pizzeria) 
on July 15, 2011.  No analytes were detected in the indoor air sample indicating that the Bank 
has not likely been significantly affected by this release.  However, a concentration of PCE of 
102 ug/m3 and a concentrations of TCE of 52 ug/m3 were present in TC Landos indicating an IH 
existed. 
 
On July 26, 2011, an indoor air sample was collected from the rear of Duds.  Results indicated 
the concentration of PCE and TCE were 239 and 181 ug/m3, respectively.  These results 
indicated that an IH existed within the rear of Duds. 
 
On August 19, 2001, one week after commencement of SVE system operations, indoor air 
samples were collected from Supercuts, the front and rear of Duds, TC Landos, and Dunkin 
Donuts. Results indicated significant decrease in indoor air concentrations in all four businesses.  
Most notably, concentrations of PCE and TCE detected at Supercuts and Dunkin Donuts were 
below the commercial/industrial threshold values.  Concentrations of PCE and TCE detected at 
TC Landos were 15 and 13 ug/m3, respectively, as compared to 102 and 52 ug/m3 prior to SVE 
implementation. 
 
On August 19, 2011, the concentrations of PCE and TCE detected in the rear of Duds were 150 
and 60.7 ug/m3, respectively, as compared to 239 and 181 ug/m3 prior to SVE implementation.  
These data suggest that although indoor air quality improved, an IH condition still existed in the 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

rear of Duds.  Accordingly, EnChem and E&A implemented plans to expand the SVE system.  
However, concentrations of PCE and TCE in the front of Duds (near the front desk/customer 
pick up and drop off area) were 15 and 12 ug/m3, suggesting that the front portion of Duds is 
significantly less impacted than the rear of Duds. 

4.7 Notification to Tenants of Imminent Hazard 
 
In accordance with 310 CMR 1403(11), the owners/occupants of Supercuts, TC Landos, and 
Duds were provided verbal notification of the IH condition within 72 hours of EnChem and 
E&A obtaining knowledge of such conditions.  Written notifications were provided within 7 
days of verbal notification. Copies of the notifications provided to the tenants are included in 
Appendix I. 
 

4.8  Current Imminent Hazard Evaluation 
 
As described above, E&A has undertaken significant actions to mitigate the IH that was 
identified at the Site on July 12, 2011.  Accordingly, the most recently obtained indoor air data 
from Supercuts, Duds, and TC Landos is considered to most accurately represent potential risks 
to employees, customers, and visitors to these retail facilities. Details of the calculations are 
presented in the IH Evaluation included in Appendix J.  
 
The IH evaluation was performed in accordance with the MCP 310 CMR 40.0950 assuming a 5 
year period of exposure for a full-time worker present at the Site for 8-hours per day, 250 days 
per year (5 day work week for 50 weeks per year). Only PCE and TCE were evaluated further 
given that a documented release(s) of PCE is known to have occurred at the Site and that only 
PCE and TCE have been detected in soil vapor and indoor air samples. 
 
The 5-year exposure period is likely highly conservative considering the fact that an SVE system 
is currently in operation at the Disposal Site and concentrations of PCE and TCE detected in 
indoor air have already been significantly reduced.  
 
Based on the most recent indoor air results, the IH conditions previously identified at Supercuts 
and TC Landos no longer exist.  The IRA activities performed to date have successfully 
mitigated the IH at these establishments.  However, given the significant concentrations of 
VOCs being recovered by the SVE system, IRA activities remain necessary to continue to 
mitigate the potential for impacts to indoor air. 
 
The data suggest that an IH condition continues to exist in the rear of Duds.  Accordingly, the 
SVE system is being expanded with additional deeper, vertically oriented SVE wells to be 
installed through the floor slab at Duds.  Additionally, in-situ chemical oxidation (ISCO) will be 
implemented to remediate deeper soil and groundwater beneath and adjacent to Duds.  Details of 
these remedial measures are presented in the following sections. 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

 

5.0   IMMEDIATE RESPONSE ACTION PLAN 
 
The following sections describe additional remediation and monitoring activities that will be 
performed at the Site under this IRA Plan. The objective of the IRA is to remove VOCs that were 
identified during the investigations performed by EnChem and in historical site investigations 
performed by SHA and C&C from indoor air, impacted unsaturated zone soil, and groundwater 
located beneath the 293-295 Main Street spaces.   These goals will be achieved through the 
continued operation and expansion of the Soil Vapor Extraction (SVE) system that commenced 
operations on August 12, 2011 (see Section 4.0 for details).  This plan includes provisions for 
additional remediation of soil and groundwater that will be performed via in-situ chemical 
oxidation (ISCO) using EnChem’s patented OxyZone Process (US Patent 7,667,087). Provisions 
for additional investigation via the installation of monitoring wells, additional soil vapor 
screening, and indoor air sampling are also included. The specific plans, proposed 
implementation schedule, and other pertinent details of the IRA are outlined in the following 
sections.  
 

5.1 SVE Expansion and SVE O&M 
 
On September 10 and 11, 2011, locations for eight potential SVE wells were cored and pre- 
cleared using a vacuum truck by CDS under the supervision of EnChem. The locations of these 
potential wells are indicated on Figure 5.  
 
The additional SVE wells will be installed on Sunday, September 18, 2011.  The wells will be 
connected to the SVE blower by September 25, 2011 and will begin operation immediately.  The 
exact wells that will be operated simultaneously will be determined based on vacuum 
measurement, SVE system influent concentrations, and ongoing soil vapor point screening data. 
 
SVE air emissions will continue to be monitored in accordance with 310 CMR 40.0049 and 
MADEP Policy #WSC-94-150 “Off-Gas Treatment of Point Source Remedial Air Emissions”. 
Ongoing PID monitoring will be performed on a monthly or more frequent basis. At a minimum, 
samples will be collected from the SVE influent and effluent on a quarterly basis and will be 
submitted to a Massachusetts certified laboratory for analysis. 
 

5.2  In-Situ Chemical Oxidation 
 
Historic soil data obtained beneath the floor slab of Duds and Supercuts, current groundwater 
data, current soil vapor sampling/screening data, and current indoor air data indicate that a 
significant release of PCE has impacted soil from immediately below the floor slab in Duds to 
the water table (depth approximately 15 feet) under the floor slab. Currently SVE is being 
implemented to eliminate migration of vapors to indoor air and to reduce concentrations of 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

VOCs in unsaturated, shallow soil.  However, to remediate deeper soil and groundwater and 
control potential migration of vapors from groundwater and deeper soil to indoor air, in-situ 
chemical oxidation (ISCO) will be implemented using EnChem’s patented OxyZone® process 
(US Patent No. 7,667,087).  Details of ISCO are provided in the following sections.  
 

5.2.1 Relevant Design Parameters for OxyZone® Injections 
 
OxyZone is a blend of KlozurTM sodium persulfate (a trademarked product of FMC Corporation), 
dissolved ozone, dilute hydrogen peroxide, and food-grade phosphate based buffers. OxyZone® 
is applied using the EnChem mobile treatment unit trailer.  No metals are added to OxyZone®.    
OxyZone is very safe to apply as the reactions generate negligible heat and off gas during 
injection and following injection. OxyZone provides a broad spectrum of chemical reactions and 
reaction rates from fast to medium to slow with some oxidants remaining effective for weeks to 
months after injection allowing remediation to occur significant distances from the injection 
wells.  EnChem has successfully and safely implemented OxyZone adjacent to and under 
occupied structures, including residential properties. Oxidants are temporarily stored in a locking 
storage unit. 
 
An initial application of approximately 10,000 gallons of OxyZone is proposed under and behind 
Duds.  The exact injection protocol will be determined based on the rate of oxidant acceptance at 
individual injectors, the observed distribution of oxidants during and following application, and 
ongoing monitoring data.  The proposed locations of injection wells are indicated on Figure 5.  
Note that ISCO may be performed using wells that are periodically used for SVE and/or SVE 
may be performed at wells installed primarily for ISCO. 
 
To monitor the distribution of oxidants through the subsurface, EnChem will monitor field 
parameters (pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), oxidation reduction potential (ORP), conductivity, and 
temperature) at selected monitoring wells and injection wells on a daily basis.  OxyZone 
typically raises ORP, DO, and conductivity as oxidants reach the wells. Additionally, indoor air 
and the SVE off-gas will be periodically screened for the presence of ozone during injections. 
The pH can change slightly either slightly up or down depending on the starting pH, and the 
amount of organic carbon present in site soils.  EnChem will adjust the specific volume of 
oxidants injected at each injector as needed based on field monitoring results to optimize the 
distribution of oxidants. If warranted, additional injectors may be installed to optimize oxidant 
distribution. 
 
 

5.2.2 Construction Plan and Specifications  
 
OxyZone is mixed and injected using EnChem’s mobile treatment unit. EnChem designed and 
built the trailer to maximize efficiency and safety during injections and is responsible for the 
operation and maintenance of the system.  The EnChem trailer is a self-contained modular 
system capable of multiple oxidant delivery in liquid form or gaseous form if needed. The 
oxidants are injected at a rate of approximately 1 – 5 gallons per minute depending on the 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

hydraulic conductivity of the formation. The injection pressures are typically less than 10 pounds 
per square inch (psi). EnChem personnel are present at all times during ISCO injection to 
monitor the equipment, the progress of the injections, and related groundwater parameters. 
 
No permanent equipment other than the injection wells are required to implement the proposed 
remedial measures. 
 

5.2.3 Operation, Maintenance, and Monitoring 
 
During ISCO injection, EnChem will operate the mobile treatment trailer daily from 
approximately 8 AM to 5 PM with an EnChem employee present at all times. EnChem performs 
regular maintenance on the trailer. EnChem keeps daily logs of all chemical and volumes 
injected. In accordance with the MCP, EnChem also maintains hydraulic control of all injectants 
by monitoring pH, ORP, and conductivity within a 50 foot radius of the target area of injection 
as well as groundwater elevation in select monitoring wells on a daily basis. Ozone levels within 
indoor and outdoor air are also monitored. 
 

5.3 Additional Assessment Activities 
 
The following assessment activities will be performed as part of IRA and Comprehensive 
Response Actions. 
 

5.3.1  Indoor Air Sampling 
 
Indoor air samples will be collected from Supercuts, Duds, and TC Landos in October 2011 to 
evaluate progress of the ongoing IRA.  The data will be evaluated to determine the date of the 
next indoor air sampling event. Indoor air sampling is expected to be performed on a quarterly 
basis (or more frequent basis) after October 2011. 
 

5.3.2   Monitoring Well Installation  
 
Up to 10 additional monitoring wells will be installed on the Upper and Lower Plaza to more 
accurately determine the current nature and extent of VOC impacts to groundwater associate 
with this release.  Potential monitoring well locations are indicated on Figure 6. 
 

5.3.3  Soil Vapor Point Installation and Sampling, Lower Plaza 
 
Due to the detection of PCE at concentrations above Method 1 GW-2 standards at monitoring 
wells MW-7, EC-9 and EC-10, a potential exists for migration of vapors to indoor air.  
Accordingly, EnChem will install up to 6 soil vapor monitoring points through the floor slab of 
the building on Lower Plaza.  Soil vapor samples will initially be screened using a calibrated 
PID.  If vapors are detected with a PID, soil vapor samples will be collected using Summa 
canisters equipped with 8-hour regulators and submitted to Massachusetts certified laboratory for 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

analysis of VOCs via EPA Method TO-15.  IF PID screening suggests that VOC vapors are not 
present in soil gas, summa samples will not be collected. 
 

5.3.4  Groundwater Sampling and Gauging 
 
Groundwater sampling and water level gauging will be performed on a semi-annual (or more 
frequent basis, as warranted).  Groundwater samples will be collected from selected monitoring 
wells on Upper and Lower Plaza and submitted to a Massachusetts certified laboratory for 
analysis.  The next groundwater sampling and gauging event is scheduled to be performed in 
October 2011. 
 

6.0 SAFETY, PERMITS, WASTE MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT 
 
The following sections detail the health and safety, permitting, waste management, and public 
involvement aspects of the proposed Phase IV activities, as required by the MCP. 

6.1  Health & Safety Plan 
 
EnChem has prepared a site-specific health and safety plan (HASP) that will be used during well 
installation and operation of the SVE system, as required by 310 CMR 40.0018.  This Health and 
Safety Plan will be on site during all field activities described herein, and will be monitored and 
updated as observations and/or data encountered deem necessary.  

6.2   Federal, State, and Local Permits 
 
No federal, state and/or local permits are required to perform the scope of work described herein. 
 

6.3   Remediation Waste 
 
Soil generated during SVE well and vapor point installation will be temporarily stored on-site in 
labeled 55-gallon drums, characterized, and subsequently transported to an appropriately 
licensed facility for disposal under a hazardous waste manifest.  Any spent carbon used in the 
SVE system will be recycled (if feasible), therefore it is not considered remediation waste. Spent 
carbon will be transported by an appropriately licensed contractor under a Hazardous Waste 
Manifest.   

6.4  Public Involvement 
 
In accordance with the MCP [310 CMR 40.1403(3)], EnChem on behalf of E&A has furnished 
notification of document availability (NODA) for this IRA to the Board of Selectman and the 
Board of Health of Acton.  The document is available for public review via the MADEP website.  
Copies of the notification letters are included in Appendix K. 



 

EnChem Engineering, Inc. 2011 

 

7.0 IMPLEMENTATION SCHEDULE 
 
The implementation of the described IRA activities will be conducted in accordance with the 
following schedule during the reporting period between September 16 and November 16, 2011.  
 
September 2011  Install additional SVE wells.  Install ISCO injection wells.  Install monitoring 

wells. 
Sept./Oct.  2011  Install and screen soil gas points at Lower Plaza 
Oct. 2011  Perform SVE emissions testing.  Perform indoor air sampling. 
Nov. 2011  Initial ISCO Injection.  Indoor air sampling. SVE emissions testing. 
Nov. 16, 2011 IRA Status Report No. 1 Due.  The status report will include an updated 

schedule. 
 

8.0      LSP OPINION 
 
The LSP Opinion is provided on the BWSC-105 IRA Transmittal Form. Raymond G Ball, Ph.D., 
P.E., L.S.P, is the LSP-of-Record for the site. 
 
This IRA Plan contains material facts, data, and other information that supports the LSP Opinion 
that the response actions that are the subject of this submittal: a) are being implemented in 
accordance with the applicable provisions of M.G.L.c.21E and 310 CMR 40.0000; b) are 
appropriate and reasonable to accomplish the purposes of such response actions as set forth in 
the applicable provisions of M.G.L.c.21E and 310 CMR 40.0000; and c) comply with the 
identified provisions of all orders, permits, and approvals identified in this submittal.  
 
 
If you have any questions regarding this IRA Plan, please contact the undersigned.

EnChem Engineering, Inc.
